entries.title: First Simulated Images of Two Black Holes Colliding
entries.excerpt: The equations of general relativity are so fiendish that nobody has been able to work out what a collision between two black holes would look like...until now

entries.title: A Neuroscience Correlate of Consciousness
entries.excerpt: Neuroskeptic goes in-depth with Srivas Chennu

entries.title: The fastest autonomous car on the planet
entries.excerpt: Audi put a big exclamation point on its self-driving technology — "piloted driving," as the company calls it — with an adrenaline-filled demonstration..

entries.title: How a computer error helped Deep Blue beat humanity's best chess player
entries.excerpt: When Deep Blue beat Garry Kasparov

entries.title: Festo's SmartBird robot takes off with elegance
entries.excerpt: The geniuses at Festo's Bionic Learning Network are well known for their fascination with robotic animals, and their latest creation is no exception...

entries.title: jQuery Plugin: switchStyler
entries.excerpt: Add/Remove css classes when something fixed is hovering your target div(s).

entries.title: Russel Foster:Why do we sleep?
entries.excerpt: Russell Foster is a circadian neuroscientist: He studies the sleep cycles of the brain. And he asks: What do we know about sleep?

entries.title: Peacock Spider
entries.excerpt: This is the peacock spider Maratus volans. Jürgen Otto was the first to film this spider's mating dance.

entries.title: Daniel Wolpert: The real reason for brains
entries.excerpt: Neuroscientist Daniel Wolpert starts from a surprising premise: the brain evolved, not to think or feel, but to control movement.

entries.title: Antonio Damasio: The quest to understand consciousness
entries.excerpt: Every morning we wake up and regain consciousness — that is a marvelous fact — but what exactly is it that we regain? Neuroscientist Antonio Damasio uses this simple question to give us a glimpse into how our brains create our sense of self.

entries.title: Henry Markram: A brain in a supercomputer
entries.excerpt: Henry Markram says the mysteries of the mind can be solved — soon. Mental illness, memory, perception: they're made of neurons and electric signals, and he plans to find them with a supercomputer that models all the brain's 100,000,000,000,000 synapses.

entries.title: Oliver Sacks: What hallucination reveals about our minds
entries.excerpt: Neurologist and author Oliver Sacks brings our attention to Charles Bonnet syndrome — when visually impaired people experience lucid hallucinations. He describes the experiences of his patients in heartwarming detail and walks us through the biology of this under-reported phenomenon.

entries.title: Frans Lanting: The story of life in photographs
entries.excerpt: In this stunning slideshow, celebrated nature photographer Frans Lanting presents The LIFE Project, a poetic collection of photographs that tell the story of our planet, from its eruptive beginnings to its present diversity.

entries.title: Daniel Dennet: The illusion of consciousness
entries.excerpt: Philosopher Dan Dennett makes a compelling argument that not only don't we understand our own consciousness, but that half the time our brains are actively fooling us.
